thread.title: Top 10 wonderful woods where you'll fall in love with the glory of autumn
thread.title_full: Top 10 wonderful woods where you'll fall in love with the glory of autumn - Mirror Online

author: Nigel Thompson
title: Top 10 wonderful woods where you'll fall in love with the glory of autumn
text:
Summer, such as it was, is a fast fading memory. But autumn – the season of mists and mellow fruitfulness according to Keats – has a beauty all of its own.
While we fret about how long we can manage without turning on the heating, there’s a warm glow to be enjoyed in the countryside .
So get out that hat and coat and go for a walk among the golden leaves. The Woodland Trust has compiled its 10 favourite forests for an autumn amble. The Trust owns hundreds of woods, so there’s bound to be one near you.
For a list of autumn events visit woodlandtrust.org.uk/get-involved/events/ and to find your nearest autumn wood visit woodlandtrust.org.uk/autumn 1: Nidd Gorge: Knaresborough, N Yorks Nidd Gorge Woods
Made up of five woods – Coalpits Wood, Bilton Banks, Spring Wood, Scotton Banks and Gates Wood – walkers may spot roe deer, tawny owls, herons and woodpeckers
here, plus various reptiles and amphibians. It’s also home to 91 species of fungi, such as puffballs, cup fungi, jelly and bracket fungi.
Public footpaths run through the woods and along the river bank, linking the gorge to lovely Harrogate, Knaresborough and the surrounding area.
2: Bunkers Hill: Stourbridge, Staffs Bunkers Hill Wood, Stourbridge Staffs
There’s a mix of mature broadleaves and conifers including sweet chestnut, oak, Scots pine and Corsican pine and also areas of regenerated birch. An extensive network of rides and paths criss-cross the site, as well as large open glades of bracken and grassland which provide a haven for plants, flowers and butterflies. There are good views at Kinver Edge.
3: Wentwood: Newport, Gwent Wentwood Forest
Part of a concentration of ancient woodlands between the rivers Usk and Wye in Wales. The site is a haven for wildlife. Dormice can be found, together with adders, lizards, deer and birds including the nightjar. The wood has a number of ancient monuments surrounding it and a bronze age burial mound.
4: Hucking Estate: Maidstone, Kent Hucking Estate woods
Large and diverse with a mix of ancient woodland, open grassland, archaeology remains and fine views all set in the Kent Downs Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty (AONB).
Visitors can meander among old oak, lime and beech or newer yew, whitebeam and wild cherry. Interpretation boards and leaflets on-site explain features such as the wood banks, chalk and marl pits and an ancient drove road.
5: Crinan Woods: Crinan, Argyll and Bute Crinan Woods
Crinan Wood rises more than 300ft above the picturesque coastal village of the same name. The Crinan Canal borders the site and the famous Corryvreckan whirlpool is a few miles out to sea (if it’s really wild you can hear it from the woods). Crinan’s moist, mild climate it is often described as a remnant of Scotland’s own rainforest and the native oak wood is home to a variety of ferns and lichens plus 24 species of birds including buzzard, tree creeper, redstart and wood warbler.
Prehen Wood: Derry Prehen Woods
A remnant of the extensive woodland that once covered much of the east bank of the River Foyle, stretching as far as Strabane.
Visitors can wander among beech interspersed with hazel, holly and oak and perhaps a glimpse of inhabitants which include the red squirrel, sparrowhawk and long-
eared owl.
There are 40 minute or 20 minute circular walks.
7: Brede High Woods: Cripps Corner, E Sussex Brede High Woods
At 648 acres, this is one of the biggest Woodland Trust sites in England and within the High Weald AONB.
The site comprises 10 separate ancient woods that are full of banks, ditches and sunken tracks.
Its past use can be seen in the extensive earthworks caused by the excavation of iron ore. The great variety of trees usually gives spectacular autumn colours well into November.
8: Clanger & Picket Woods: Westbury, Wilts Clanger Woods
A collection of three woods, with Picket to the north separated only from Clanger by an old earthwall-sided track.
They are a Site of Special Scientific Interest due to the butterfly and moth populations, which includes important species such as the scarce silver-washed fritillary and Duke of Burgundy butterflies. More than 300 species of moth have been recorded, including the rare small eggar moth and arrow-bordered bee hawk moth.
9: Millook Valley: Bude, Cornwall Millook Valley Woods
Tucked in a deep coastal valley, these woods are not immediately obvious unless you visit nearby headlands or high ground.
The shelter helps to create an idyllic setting of woodland around lush meadow with sounds of sea breezes, birdsong and running streams.
Wildlife includes otters and bats.
10: Tring Park: Tring, Herts Tring Park
The 264-acre site is one of the Trust’s most diverse, comprising mixed woodland and chalk grassland.
Once part of the Rothschild estate (the family’s zoological museum is now part of the Natural History Museum) it lies within the Chilterns AONB.
An autumn stroll down the King Charles Ride will be graced by colour provided by the avenue of lime trees.
DailyMirror
